abstract: Returns the dominant language of the string set for the linguistic tagger.

codeExamples.code:
let text = "Die Kleinen haben friedlich zusammen gespielt."
let tagger = NSLinguisticTagger(tagSchemes: [.language], options: 0)
tagger.string = text
tagger.dominantLanguage // "de"

overview:
## Return Value

The BCP-47 tag identifying the dominant language of the string, or the tag “und” if a specific language cannot be determined.

## Discussion

If you want to know the dominant language of a string that you’re analyzing with a linguistic tagger (for example, identifying part of speech for each word), specify the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSLinguisticTagScheme/language] tag scheme in the initializer. After you set the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSLinguisticTagger/string] property of the linguistic tagger, the dominant language can be determined with the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSLinguisticTagger/dominantLanguage] property, as shown in this example:

In the example, the BCP-47 language tag “de” is returned as the dominant language, indicating that the text is in German.

# dominantLanguage

**Instance Property**

Returns the dominant language of the string set for the linguistic tagger.

## Declaration

```swift
var dominantLanguage: String? { get }
```

## Return Value

The BCP-47 tag identifying the dominant language of the string, or the tag “und” if a specific language cannot be determined.

## Discussion

If you want to know the dominant language of a string that you’re analyzing with a linguistic tagger (for example, identifying part of speech for each word), specify the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSLinguisticTagScheme/language] tag scheme in the initializer. After you set the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSLinguisticTagger/string] property of the linguistic tagger, the dominant language can be determined with the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSLinguisticTagger/dominantLanguage] property, as shown in this example:

```swift
let text = "Die Kleinen haben friedlich zusammen gespielt."
let tagger = NSLinguisticTagger(tagSchemes: [.language], options: 0)
tagger.string = text
tagger.dominantLanguage // "de"
```

In the example, the BCP-47 language tag “de” is returned as the dominant language, indicating that the text is in German.

## Determining the Dominant Language and Orthography

- **dominantLanguage(for:)**: Returns the dominant language for the specified string.
- **orthography(at:effectiveRange:)**: Returns the orthography at the index and also returns the effective range.
- **setOrthography(_:range:)**: Sets the orthography for the specified range.
